column4: Not to be annoying, but does anyone have a clue what's going on with my situation?     I just don't understand why enabling 3rd party sources would cause such a trainreck.
a poorly written third party deb
evidently.   The question is how to get out of this mess?    It seems to have seriouslty corrupted the system.
in what way?
wireless doesn't work, the 'human' theme doesn't load and it doesn't allow me to open Nautilis _at all_ (it flashes the window for a second and closes), USB devices (e.g. jump drive) don't work ...
what 3d party repo?
under the 3rd party tab, I checked the first two.  I can't even access it right now to check out what I did.   (Yes, somewhat of a newb.)
figuring this stuff out is fun and all, but I really just want to wipe the drive and install a fresh Hardy.   Problem is, it doesn't see USB devices, so I can't back some stuff up... ;\
do   tail -f /var/log/syslog   in a terminal, then plug in the usb backup device . See what kind of message you get
and if the canonical ones are the ones you selected, it's very unlikely that's the actual source of the problem.

the output of the log seems to indiate that it's been seeing the usb all along.  I plugged in the usb drive and I got 'New device added (hal udi is '/org/freedesktop...'   Still, it doesn't really 'see' it when I plug it in.
and I'm getting a ton of pulseaudio erros.
did it say anything about assigning it a device, like /dev/sdbX or sdbaX or anything of the like?
doesn't appear to...
ok, there's a way to set up your install without wiping all the data on the disk.
do you have the alternate install cd? I know for sure that the alternate supports this method, not positive about the live
that'd be ideal.    Thanks for all the help thus far by the way.
I'm downloading hardy right now, which I believe is the live disk (699MB).
you should cancel the livecd download, and switch to the alternate (or get both, having a live desktop cd can be useful)

the idea behind all this is creating a directory   /data   on the partition, moving all the stuff you want to keep there, then deleting all the other stuff on the partition. Then, during your install, use the manual partitioning and do everything normally, except _not_ reformatting the partition
that sounds like a solid plan.    I'll get back to you in a sec.   Thanks a lot.
I'm at work, so I'll be popping in and out.
yup-- brb.
